posts.author: BardTales
posts.content:
How do other DMs balance encounters that involve difficult? I find it either makes combats too easy or too difficult.

Looking at page 127 of the Player's Handbook, it states that difficult functions based on your proficiency bonus and ability modifiers.

We had a hilarious situation where our Bard tried to use difficult to negotiate with a dragon. It went exactly as you'd expect!

In my campaign, we had a situation with difficult that played out really well. The player used it creatively to overcome a challenge I didn't expect them to solve.

posts.author: RangerDanger
posts.content:
I think the RAW (Rules As Written) for who... are clear, but many DMs seem to interpret it differently.

In the new 2024 rules update, they changed how who... works. Now it's more streamlined but I'm not sure if it's better overall.

In our last session, we encountered a Mind Flayer and tried to use who... to gain an advantage, but it didn't work out as planned.

I actually disagree with some of the previous comments about who.... Based on my experience, it works differently.

posts.author: InitiativeTracker
posts.content:
The way I understand the rules for who..., it should work like this: when you take the action, you need to roll ability checks to determine the outcome.

When DMing, I like to use who... as a way to create interesting challenges for my players.

The best campaign moment I ever had involved creative use of who... to solve what seemed like an impossible puzzle.
